questions.text: A male came to the ER after car accident. He had dyspnea and chest pain with ecchymosis on anterior chest wall. On examination, pulse -120/min, BP-80/50mmHg, breaths sounds were decreased on left side, JVP was raised and tympanic note was present on percussion. Pelvis and extremities were normal. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-In tension pneumothorax, Breath sounds will be decreased due to compression of lung by air in pleural cavity.Tympanic note on percussion will be heared due to air and obstructive shock can result in hypotension with increased pulse rate and raised JVP. Option B-Massive hemothorax will be dull on percussion. Option C-Cardiac tamponade will not cause tympanic note. Option D-In case of hydropneumothorax ,dull note will be heard on percussion due to fluid.

questions.text: The given image shows methylene blue being injected in the peritumoral region. Which of the given procedure is being performed?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Dye is injected around tumour [periareolar region], then we have to wait for 15mins. First few LNs which take up the dye are known as Sentinel LNs. Biopsy of those LNs is done for presence of metastasis. If LNs are negative [no tumour cells]there is no need of axillary surgery. Combination of blue dye [methylene blue] + radiolabelled dye [colloid sulphur] is used.

questions.text: Class 3 hemorrhagic shock refers to-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Hemorrhagic shock are classified into following classes:- class 1-<15% blood loss class 2-15-30% blood loss class 3-30-40% blood loss class 4->40% blood loss

questions.text: An intubated patient with eye opening to pain with abnormal flexion. What is the GCS score?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Eye opening to pain-E2 Intubated patient-therefore vocal response cannot be tested i.e,NT. Abnormal flexion-M3

questions.text: The correct procedure of inserting the following equipment in the image given below:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The given image shows nasogastric tube,also known as Ryle's tube. Length measurement of nasogastric tube - from Tip of nose to earlobe to xiphisternum. For insertion,Patient should be sitting comfortably with slight flexion of neck. This is not done in supine position as patient may vomit and there is risk of aspiration in supine position.

questions.text: Where is the second step of damage control resuscitation carried out?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) DCS - PHASES are as follows:- Phase 0 - prehospital assessment Phase 1 - abbreviated surgery [laparotomy for around 35- 40mins] Phase 2 - Done in ICU :- resuscitation and Correction of trauma triad of death which includes Hypothermia, Acidosis and Coagulopathy Phase 3 Definitive surgery within 48 hours. Phase 4 - abdominal wall closure.

questions.text: A 50-years-old male presented in the emergency with high BP (160/100) and heart rate of 120. A CECT is done which is given below. What is the next step in management.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The given image shows Aortic dissection involving the Ascending aorta with sparing of descending aorta [hence,It is Debakey Type II] First step of Management in aortic dissection is to Control the heart rate by short acting beta blocker like esmolol. [HR Goal The definitive management includes:- Type 1 & Type 2 debakey - Surgical repair using Dacron graft replacement. Type 3 - Conservative management There is no role of vitamin K inhibiots and heparin in management of aortic dissection.

questions.text: Palpation of breast from outside to inside, then from inside to outside. What is the method of palpation called as
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Image A is k/s Dial clock method Option B-Image B is k/s vertical stripes method Option C-Image C is k/s Wedges/ Quadrant Option D-Image D is k/s Concentric circlemethod in which palpation of breast is done from outside to inside, then from inside to outside

questions.text: More conspicuous sign of breast cancer is-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Puckering is due to involvement of Cooper's ligament.It can occur in other diseases as well. Option B-Circumferential retraction of nipple in breast Cancer is due to involvement of lactiferous ducts.However,slit like nipple retraction is seen in duct ectasia. Option D-Peau De Orange is due to blockage of subdermal Lymphatics by tumour cells.It is a more conspicuous sign of breast cancer.

questions.text: A patient came to ER after RTA. He is conscious, could speak in single word sentences. RR-40/min and BP-70/40 mm Hg. What will be your next step?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Intubating the patient won't help unless you remove air from pleural cavity. Option B-Urgent fluid infusion is not the first step as according to ABCDE,airway and breathing should be controlled first followed by circulation. Option C-There is no time for Chest X-Ray in such emergency condition. Option D-The given case scenario indicates tension pneumothorax as patient is having respiratory distress along with hypotension.Next step in case of tension pneumothorax is Needle insertion in 5th ICS along mid axillary line.

questions.text: Young male presents with diarrhoea.Resident wants to give rapid fluids, which cannula should he choose:-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Gray cannula with Flow rate of 180 ml/min. For Fluids- best is gray >> green>pink>blue>yellow. Because Rate of flow is directly proportional to radius and inversely proportional to length.

questions.text: The machine shown in given image is used for:-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-The given image shows Pneumatic compression device/ DVT pump which is used to compress the calf muscles,so that blood can flow towards heart and stasis can be prevented,thereby,reducing chances of DVT. Option B-Pneumatic compression device/ DVT pump is used for prevention of DVT,not Varicose veins. Option C,D-Fracture and Cellulitis have nothing to do with Pneumatic compression device/ DVT pump.

questions.text: The below picture is used for which of the following procedure:-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The given image shows Humby's knife which is used for taking split skin graft.

questions.text: Color code of 16F Foley's catheter is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Fr is outer diameter and 1mm=3 Fr. The colour coding of different foley's catheter is given below:- Green-14fr Orange-16fr Red-18fr Yellow-20fr

questions.text: What is the instrument shown in the below picture?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The given image shows Chemoport,which is placed in central vein [ subclavian >>internal jugular].A chemo port is a small, implantable reservoir with a thin silicone tube that attaches to a vein. The main advantage of this vein-access device is that chemotherapy medications can be delivered directly into the port rather than a vein, eliminating the need for needle sticks.

choices.text: Rough Handling of thyroid during operative period

questions.text: Which of the following is the reason for Post op thyroid storm.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Thyroid storm refers to High T3 and T4 in circulation. Thyroid storm is an acute exacerbation of acute Hyperthyroidism. It can occur before Sx , during Sx or after Sx. Causes are as follows: A) Inadequate preparation with drugs before thyroidectomy (Most common cause) B) Stress C) URTI D) Rough handling of the gland causing release of the thyroid hormone,but it is not the most common cause. 5) Discontinuation of propranolol immediately after Sx.

questions.text: A patient was operated for pilonidal sinus.The surgeon wanted to close the wound with the flap as shown below. What type of flap did the surgeon use to close the defect?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Thew given image shows Rhomboid/ Limberg flap.The design is a parallelogram with two angles of 120° and two angles of 60°. All sides are equal. Option B-A rotation flap is a semicircular skin flap that is rotated into the defect on a fulcrum point. Option C-A free flap is a piece of tissue that is disconnected from its' original blood supply, and is moved a significant distance to be reconnected to a new blood supply. Option D- Advancement flaps are technically characterized by sliding or stretching the flap skin along a single vector.

choices.text: Give tranexamic acid in initial hours
Give 2 liters of crystalloids fast as initial fluid

questions.text: 45yr old man with RTA, feeble pulse, and hypotension. All of the following are lines of management except.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Thromboelastography/ rotational thromboelastometry [TEG/ROTEM] is done to look for coagulation abnormalities. Option B-Trenexamic acid within 3 hours is given,1gm iv bolus followed by 1gm iv every 8 hourly. Option C-Give 1 litre of crystalloids in adults and In children-20ml/kg of crystalloids is given. Option D-Do early blood transfusion.

questions.text: All of the following are features of SIRS except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Temperature > 38'C or<36'C is a feature of SIRS. Option B-RR >20 and PaCo2 <32 is a feature of SIRS. Option C-Pulse rate > 90/minute is a feature of SIRS. Option D-WBC >12,000/mm3 or < 4000/mm3 is a feature of SIRS.

questions.text: Most common mediastinal tumor:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Neurogenic tumors ( M/C occur in posterior Mediastinum ) are the M/C mediastinal tumors in children .

questions.text: After parotidectomy patients complaints of loss of sensation while shaving. Which nerve is most likely affected?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Nerves likely to be injured in case of parotid Surgery - 1. Facial nerve -patient presents with deviation of mouth, inability to close the eyes, inability to puff cheeks, tear from eyes on same side. 2. Greater auricular nerve-causes Loss of sensation while shaving as it supplies area near angle of mandible. 3. Auriculotemporal nerve -Patient presents with Frey's syndrome,also known as gustatory sweating.Patient presents with sweating & erythema in area of parotid.It occurs due to inappropriate regeneration of post ganglionic parasympathetic nerve fibers,which unite with the sympathetic fibers of the superior cervical ganglia,which is responsibie for sweating & erythema. Mandibular nerve is not injured in parotid surgeries.

questions.text: Patient presented to emergency after RTA with multiple rib fractures. He is conscious, speaking single words. On examination, respiratory rate was 40/min and BP was 90/40 mmHg. What is immediate next step?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The increased respiratory rate with hypotension,along with history of multiple rib fractures suggests diagnosis of tension pneumothorax. Option A-Urgent IV fluid administration is not the 1st step as airway and breathing should be controlled prior to circulation. Option B-Intubate the patient won't help as lung is collapsed by air in pleural cavity. Option C-X-ray is not done as patient is unstable. Option D-Inserting Needle in 5th intercostal space is the immediate next step in case of tension pneumothorax to remove excess air followed by ICD tube in 5th intercostal space.

questions.text: Percentage of surgical site infection rate in patient with clean contaminated wounds after antibiotics prophylaxis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) SSI wounds are classified into following classes:- Class I=1 to 2% =Clean Wound, hollow viscera not opened.Example-breast/thyroid/ hernia Surgery CLASS II = CLASS III =10 TO 30% =CONTAMINATED, gross spillage from hollow viscera.Example- early accidental wound. CLASS IV =30 to 40 % =Dirty.Example-late accidental wound, pus, gangrene, fecal matter.

questions.text: Correct order of removing Personal Protective Equipment (PPE): 1. Gown 2. Mask 3. Face shield 4. Gloves
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Correct order of removing Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) is: 4. Gloves 1. Gown 3. Face shield 2. Mask

questions.text: Which of the following is not the component of qSOFA?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) qSOFA score includes the following:- 1.RR >22/min 2.Altered mental status 3.Systolic BP <100mmHg Bilateral pupillary reflex is not a component of qSOFA score.

choices.text: Thyroglossal duct obliterates by 18th weeks of IUL
Lining epithelium is non-ciliated stratified squamous epithelium

questions.text: Which of the following is true about thyroglossal cyst?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Secondary infection leads to abscess formation,which if ruptures or if I&D is done,it can lead to fistula/ sinus formation. Option B-40% of thyroglossal cyst contains heterotopic thyroid tissue. Option C-Thyroglossal duct obliterates by 7th to 8th week of IUL. Option D-Lining epithelium is pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium. Leaving the thyroglossal cyst intact can lead to formation of Papillary Thyroid Cancer later.

questions.text: Which of the following does not classify as locally advanced breast cancer?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 1.Any T4,any N2, any N3 → locally advanced breast cancer 2.T1 T2 T3, EITHER N0/N1→Early breast cancer Option A-Tumor more than 4 cm can be T2,hence it is not considered as locally advanced breast cancer. Option B-Inflammatory breast cancer is T4d,hence considered as locally advanced breast cancer. Option C-Chest wall involvement is T4a,,hence considered as locally advanced breast cancer. Option D-Skin involvement is T4b,hence considered as locally advanced breast cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following scoring system is used for wound infection?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-SIRS Score as the name suggests,is for SIRS. Option B-ASA score is given for physical status of patient undergoing surgery. Option C-Southampton score is used for wound infection.The grading is given below. Option D-Glasgow coma score is used for neurological assessment.

questions.text: Most common artery involved in pseudoaneurysm:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) In pseudoaneurysm all the layers are not involved, outer layer is intact and will be holding the blood Most common site of pseudoaneurysm-Femoral artery Most common site of central aneurysm-aorta Most common site of peripheral aneurysm-Popliteal artery Most common site of visceral aneurysm-splenic artery overall Most common aneurysm in body-berry aneurysm,present in circle of willis in Brain.

questions.text: Best way to manage the wound shown in image is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-The given image shows Abrasion of epithelium and minor skin loss.It can heal spontaneously.hence,Cleaning and dressing is recommended in such situations. Option B-Debridement is done in cases of dead and necrotic tissue. Option C,D-skin grafting like allograft is not done in cases of abrasion.

questions.text: Identify the name of the disease shown here in the breast?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Pagets disease is insitu ductal cancer,in which whole nipple areola complex gets destroyed. Option B-The given image shows Tender Cord like structures,which is seen in cases of superficial thrombophlebitis of breast.This condition is known as Mondor’disease. No specific treatment is required. Rest, hot fomentation, anti-inflammatory are the mainstay of treatment. Option C-There is nothing known as Red manhood in breast. Option D-Tietz syndrome is the costochondritis of costal cartilage,therefore, patient complaints of mastalgia, problem under the breast.

questions.text: ABCDE principle is used for which malignancy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) ABCDE principle is used for Malignant melanoma,It stands for:- Asymmetry Border → Irregular Colour → Variegated Diameter >6mm Evolving → any change in size, shape, colour Any E + any of A to D → indication of BIOPSY

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in massive blood transfusion:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) In stored blood,citrate is present,which will go inside the body. Then,the liver metabolizes it and convert it into bicarbonate. Bicarbonate raises the blood pH leading to metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: Arrange the following types of renal injury in order from lower to higher grade: A. Subcapsular hematoma B. Hematomas contained in Gerota’s fascia C. Avulsion of the pedicle D. Shattered kidney
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Renal injury in order from lower to higher grade is as follows:- A. Subcapsular hematoma B. Hematomas contained in Gerota’s fascia C. Avulsion of the pedicle D. Shattered kidney

questions.text: What is the correct order followed while hand washing: A. Back of hands B. Palm to palm C. Back of finger D. Fingernails
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The correct order followed while hand washing is: B. Palm to palm A. Back of hands C. Back of finger D. Fingernails

questions.text: What is the mechanism by which the following technique works?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The given image shows VAC DRESSING,also known as VACUUM ASSISTED CLOSURE. It has a negative pressure of -125mmHg.(Remember this value,It is another PYQ.) Conditions in which it is not used :- 1. Osteomyelits 2. Malignancies 3. Open abdomen, bowel directly visible

questions.text: Identify the grade of the bed score shown in the given below image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Stage 1= ulcers have not yet broken through the skin. Stage 2= ulcers have a break in the top two layers of skin. Stage 3= ulcers affect the top two layers of skin, as well as fatty tissue. Stage 4= ulcers are deep wounds that may impact muscle, tendons, ligaments, and bone.

questions.text: What is the utility of the instrument shown in the image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The given image shows Veress needle.It is a Spring loaded needle with 14G capacity.It is used to create pneumoperitoneum. Position of patient=slight head down 2 clicks are heard while putting this needle=1st when it pierces the fascia and 2nd when it pierces the peritoneum To confirm position=do saline drop test or aspirate method. In patients with previous midline scars,Veress needle is not put as it can cause injury to bowel/ vessel.In this case-open technique is used.

questions.text: Identify the drain shown in the image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Mini vac drain is designed for low pressure suction of post-operative wounds. Option B-Romovac is a closed drain. Option C-The given image shows a Closed drainage system known as Jackson Pratt drain. Option D-Corrugated rubber drain→ open type

questions.text: Which of the following test is performed before taking sample for ABG analysis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A,C,D-Roos test,Adson’s test and Wright test are done for thoracic outlet syndrome. Option B-Allens test → Done to see integrity of palmar arch → to see both ulnar and radial artery working before taking ABG.

choices.text: Level I to V lymph nodes

questions.text: Which of the following structure is preserved in radical neck dissection
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) RND INVOLVES REMOVAL OF :- 1.I TO V LN 2.CN XI 3.IJV 4.SCM

questions.text: A young male with head trauma presented to the casualty with aspiration. Which of the following nerve is affected
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The aspiration indicates gag reflex is not working,hence, glossopharyngeal / vagus nerve is not working. The gag reflex, also known as the pharyngeal reflex, is an involuntary reflex involving bilateral pharyngeal muscle contraction and elevation of the soft palate. The afferent limb of the reflex is supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX), which inputs to the nucleus solitarius and the spinal trigeminal nucleus. The efferent limb is supplied by the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) from the nucleus ambiguus. All of these are located in the medulla.

questions.text: In the given image, which clinical test is shown:-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-The given image shows Roos test.In this test, the patient abducts and externally rotates their shoulders with the elbow at a ninety-degree angle. The patient will then open and close their hand. Fatigue or reproduction of symptoms is a positive result. Option B,D-Wright test is also known as Costoclavicular test. Option C-Adson test is also done for thoracic outlet syndrome.

questions.text: Identify the disorder seen in the image
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-This is a Classical image of Plexiform neurofibroma,involving the trigeminal nerve area. Option B-Lipoma is the most common benign tumour.It is soft and well circumscribed tumour. Option C-Sarcoma can have a retroperitoneal/musculoskeletal origin. Option D-Schwanomma occurs in CN VIII territory.It can occur at cerebellopontine angle.

questions.text: FAST stands for?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) FAST stands for Focussed assessment sonogram in trauma.

questions.text: Which injury cannot be evaluated during eFAST?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Liver injury may cause free fluid in peritoneum,hence,maybe seen on eFAST. Option B-Retroperitoneal injury causes retroperitoneal hematoma, not free fluid in peritoneum.Hence,Retroperitoneal injury cannot be evaluated during eFAST. Option C-Pneumothorax on eFAST may show loss of sea shore appearance. Option D-Pericardial injury can be seen by the 1st probe used in FAST.

choices.text: Penetrating trauma in pelvic region should be explored always
All zone 1 vascular injuries should be managed with embolization
Zone 2 penetrating injuries with expanding haematoma should be explored surgically
Mattox manoeuvre is when the ascending colon is mobilized to right to expose the aorta

questions.text: In retroperitoneal haematomas . which one of the following statements is true ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Zone 1= from aortic hiatus to sacral promontory. Zone 2= from renal hilum upto lateral wall. Zone 3= Iliac vessel zone. Treatment is based on mechanism of injury:- 1. Penetrating→ Surgery in all. 2. Blunt injury→Surgery in Zone 1 except retrohepatic IVC hematoma which can be treated conservatively, Zone 2 & 3 → non-operative management In Zone 2 → surgery → if expanding hematoma In Zone 3 → if active bleed →Angioembolization. Mattox maneuver is when descending colon is mobilized. Cattel Brasch Maneuver is when ascending colon is mobilized to right to expose the aorta.

questions.text: A patient is receiving TPN. Calulate the calories if the patient receives 100 gm of dextrose, 30 gm of amino acids and 40 gm of lipids
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 100 gm of dextrose:-It releases 4kcal/g:-4×100 = 400 30 gm of amino acids:-It also releases 4kcal/g:-30×4 = 120 40 gm of lipids:-It releases 9kcal/g:-40× 9 = 360 Hence,the total becomes:-880

questions.text: Which nerve injury is least likely during thyroid surgery ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Ansa cervicalis can be damaged during thyroid surgery as it lies close to thyroid on anterior wall of carotid sheath. Option B,C-External laryngeal nerve is the MOST COMMONLY INJURED nerve followed by RLN. Option D-Marginal mandibular nerve is well away from thyroid gland,hence it is least likely to be injured during thyroid surgery.

questions.text: A 25 year old man gets burnt when a stove bursts. His burns involve his hair , face , neck, chest on both sides and both upper limbs . what is the body surface area burnt ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) As per RULE OF 9:- Hair,face and neck area:-9% chest on both sides:-9+9=18% Both upper limbs:-9+9=18% The total becomes:-45%

choices.text: 70 year old lady with CRF on dialysis
50 year old alcoholic with liver cirrhosis
14 year old boy with multiorgan failure
35 year old female with renal failure

questions.text: 38 year old brain dead lady had signed up as an organ donor and the family also consented for same . which one is the ideal recipient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A is not a CONTRAINDICATION but is not an ideal candidate as the patient is very old. Option B if patient is currently taking some substance like alcohol,then he is not a candidate for organ transplant. Option C patient with multiorgan failure is also not a candidate for transplant. Option D D is ideal candidate as the patient is relatively young.

questions.text: 26 year old man with RTA, complicated with pelvic fracture and is transfused blood. Within a few hours, patient developed fever , oliguria , hypotension. CVP is normal but there is bleeding from the site of IV line and through the ryles tube. What is the most common diagnosis ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-In fat embolism,fever and oliguria will not be seen Breathing difficulty & petechiae will be seen. Option B-Blood transfusion reaction can cause fever,oliguria due to kidney damage,hypotension and bleeding from I.V. line. Option C-Adrenal insufficiency won't cause bleeding from I.V. line. Option D-Hemorrhagic shock usually don't cause fever.In fact,patient has cold clammy skin.

questions.text: Tamoxifen is given for breast cancer. which complication is associated with its use:-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Tamoxifen is a selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator , approved for the treatment of Estrogen Receptor positive breast cancer. It is used only in premenopausal women for 5 years in low risk patients and for 10 years in patients with a high risk of relapse ( node- positive , tumor>5cm , lymphovascular invasion). It is also known to reduce the incidence of secondary primary breast cancer in the contralateral breast. Tamoxifen increases the risk of Endometrial cancer in post-menopausal women , hence aromatase Inhibitors are used in post-menopausal women. Tamoxifen increases the risk of Endometrial cancer by 1-2% . The benefits of tamoxifen in breast cancer outweighs the risk of Endometrial cancer.

questions.text: A patient after parotid surgery on awakening noticed lower lip paralysis. which of the following nerve is most likely injured
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Mandibular branch of facial nerve supplies lower lip,hence, lower lip paralysis will occur due to injury to this branch. Option B-Injury to Main trunk of facial nerve will cause ipsilateral hemiplegia of face. Option C-Parotid duct injury cannot cause paralysis of face. Option D-Temporal branch of facial nerve supplies upper part of face.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a complication of massive transfusion
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Massive transfusion (typically defined as replacing a patient's total blood volume within 24 hours or transfusing more than 10 units of packed red blood cells) can lead to several metabolic complications due to the preservatives and additives in stored blood products. Complications include: Hypocalcemia Due to citrate in stored blood binding calcium. Hypomagnesemia Can occur similarly due to citrate binding magnesium. Hyperkalemia Stored red blood cells leak potassium over time, especially in older units. When transfused rapidly, this can cause elevated serum potassium levels.

questions.text: What is not included in MELD score
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) MELD score can be remembered with mnemonic CBI:- Creatinine, bilirubin and PT-INR.

choices.text: Needle in 5th ICS followed by ICD placement.

questions.text: A male comes to emergency with RTA, Hypotension and dyspnea. Breath sound on right side is absent. CXR is shown above. What is the management of the patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The given case scenario is of tension pneumothorax as patient is having dyspnea and hypotension with decreased breath sounds.On CXR:-collapsed right lung is seen by air in pleural cavity. Option A-Shift to OT for thoracotomy is not the 1st step. Option B-Close observation cannot be done in cases of tension pneumothorax. Option C-Put a needle in 5th ICS is the 1st step,but the best answer is D. Option D-Needle in 5th ICS followed by ICD placement is the best answer here.

choices.text: Subdural and dural trauma can be identified

questions.text: What is additional benefit of e-FAST over conventional FAST?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Pelvic trauma can be identified on normal FAST scan also. Option B-Chest Trauma can be identified by eFAST as An 'extended FAST or eFAST ' scan may be performed using left & right thoracic views to assess for pneumothorax & hemothorax. Option C,D-Subdural and dural trauma and Retroperitoneal trauma cannot be evaluated on FAST or eFAST.

questions.text: Young male with RTA and poor GCS, was intubated, having normal NCCT, no cervical injury or pelvic fracture. FAST is negative. Likely Diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) CT is normal in cases of DAI(diffuse axonal injury). MRI will show small punctate pin point bleeding spots at grey white matter junction.

questions.text: Identify the cannula size?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 16G=GREY 18G=GREEN 20G=PINK 22G=BLUE

questions.text: A lady with a breast lump of 6x6cm in upper outer quadrant with one ipsilateral enlarged axillary lymph node. Which investigation is not needed A. PET scan B. B/L breast mammogram C. Tru cut from breast mass D. Tru cut from lymph node
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The triple assessment method is used to evaluate a patient who presents with a breast lump or has any symptoms suspicious of CA breast . Triple assessment of breast lump includes the following 3 parameters: - Clinical assessment: Clinical history and physical examination of the lump - Radiological examination: USG or mammogram or both - Cytological examination: FNAC or core biopsy of the lump.(not from lymph node). This is the most commonly used method as the PPV of this combination is 99.99%. PET scan and Lymph node biopsy is not a part of the triple assessment method.

questions.text: A 60 year old lady has a massive enlargement of breast over 30 days, it is mobile over chest wall with local rise of temperature.What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) In the given scenario of 60 YEAR OLD patient, the rapid onset of the disease and the examination findings are suggestive of Inflammatory carcinoma of the breast . - Inflammatory breast cancer is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer . It mimics acute mastitis . The hallmark of Inflammatory breast carcinoma is the diffuse tumor involvement of the dermal lymphatics within the breast and the overlying skin , often without a discrete underlying tumor mass (peau d' orange appearance). The patient presents with rapidly progressive swelling of the breast, warmth , erythema and edema . A breast lump may or may not be present . - A diagnosis of Inflammatory breast carcinoma should be suspected when a patient with rapidly progressive swelling with Inflammatory skin changes does not respond to antibiotics. The imaging features with ultrasound and a mammogram is non-specific because of underlying erythema and edema . A biopsy should be done to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: Male smoker came with gangrenous ulcer on toe of left foot. He is complaining of early fatigue in right lower limb too while walking. Investigation for the diagnosis would be?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) PERIPHERAL VASCULAR DISEASE IS THE DIAGNOSIS in this case. Option A-Duplex scan is the IOC in peripheral vascular disease. Option B-Digital subtraction MRI is not the 1st line investigation as it is not easily available. Option C-CT angiogram is also not the 1st line investigation as there is risk of radiation. Option D-MR angiogram is not the 1st line investigation as it is not easily available.

questions.text: Which position is this?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) This is Reverse Trendelenberg position in which head is up and foot is down,which will cause intestines to go down,hence this position is used IN UPPER ABDOMINAL SURGERIES like cholecystectomy.

questions.text: In CEAP classification for varicose vein, Lipodermatosclerosis come under?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Lipodermatosclerosis comes under C4b. The entire CEAP classification is given below:-

questions.text: A female patient presented to hospital with right breast lump. Lump was located in UOQ with no axillary lymph nodes. Mammography revealed BIRADS 4. Patient underwent breast conservation surgery. Final HPE revealed high grade DCIS. What is the next step?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) In case of DCIS,we've to calculate VNPI(van nuys prognostic index),if the score comes between:- 4 TO 6 POINTS → WIDE LOCAL EXCISION 7 TO 9 → WIDE LOCAL EXCISION WITH RADIOTHERAPY 10 TO 12 → SIMPLE MASTECTOMY. Since age,size of lesion and margin is not given.so we cannot calculate score fully.but HIGH GRADE DCIS will give it 3 POINTS.so roughly the score will lie between 7-9,hence,radiotherapy should be given.

questions.text: A young female with history of renal calculi complaints of bone pain, abdominal cramps and psychosis. On investigation serum calcium and PTH was raised. Which of the following will be the best investigation to arrive at the definitive diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-History of renal calculi, bone pain, abdominal cramps and psychosis with raised serum calcium and PTH is s/o Hyperparathyroidism.Best investigation to localise the parathyroid is Tc-99 sestamibi scan. Option B,C-PET CT and MRI are not used commonly. Option D-USG neck can be done but best is sestamibi scan.

questions.text: Triage means
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Triage means to sort out patients in mass casualty. Triage Depends on -Salvageability, Available resources, Severity Colour coding of triage is:- Red=immediate intervention Yellow=urgent Green=ambulatory Black=dead / moribund.

questions.text: The most delayed sign of compartment syndrome
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-The most earliest sign of compartment syndrome is Pain on passive stretching. Option B-The most delayed sign of compartment syndrome is Pulselessness. Option C,D-Paralysis and Paresthesia are also seen but is not the most delayed sign.

questions.text: Angle of needle with the skin for interrupted suture should be
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Angle of needle with the skin for interrupted suture should be 90 degree.

questions.text: In a covid positive patient who was symptomatic and recovered at home without hospital admission. Elective surgery in this patient can be planned after
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Since the patient was symptomatic but didn't required hospitalisation.Such a patient can be taken for surgery after 6 weeks.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male was brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. His heart rate was 100/min, respiratory rate was 24/min. Chest X-ray is given below. Which of the following is contraindicated in him?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) In this case, a 24-year-old male involved in a road traffic accident presents with an elevated heart rate and respiratory rate, which are signs of physiological stress, likely due to chest trauma. Although the chest X-ray is not shown here, trauma of this nature commonly results in injuries such as pneumothorax, rib fractures, or pulmonary contusions. In such patients, epidural anesthesia is contraindicated because it can worsen respiratory compromise by blocking the intercostal nerves needed for effective breathing. Additionally, epidural anesthesia causes vasodilation through sympathetic blockade, which may lead to hypotension — a serious risk in trauma patients who could already be experiencing blood loss or shock. Furthermore, if a spinal injury is suspected, inserting an epidural needle could cause further neurological damage. Therefore, in the context of this trauma scenario, epidural anesthesia is contraindicated

choices.text: Tip of the nose to ear lobule to between manubrium sternum and umbilicus
Angle of mouth to ear lobule to xiphisternum
Tip of the nose to the angle of the mandible to the xiphisternum
Tip of the nose to ear lobule to the xiphisternum

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct method for measurement of NG tube?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Tip of the nose to ear lobule to the xiphisternum is the correct method for measurement of NG tube in adults. Tip of the nose to ear lobule to the midpoint between umbilicus and xiphisternum is the correct method for measurement of NG tube in infants.

questions.text: A man presented with a hematoma over the arm region and a history of stab injury. Radial and ulnar pulses are not felt. A 3.5cm longitudinal tear is noted in the brachial artery. Which of the following is the best treatment option?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-In this, big tear of brachial artery, primary repair will not be done as there are chances of stenotic narrowing. Option B-Repair with prosthetic graft is not commonly done as we've autologous graft like saphenous vein. Option C-Autologous reverse saphenous graft can be used to bypass/ repair that area. Option D-Repair with saphenous vein patch is not done.we've to reverse the saphenous vein graft and then put it,as there are valves present in vein.

questions.text: A patient underwent mastectomy and a drain was inserted beneath the flap. What type of drain is it?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The given image shows Romovac drain.It is a Closed type of drain. It is removed when output from drain is <30 ml in 24 hours for 2 consecutive days.

questions.text: In a patient with breast cancer, IHC is ordered. For what value of HER2/neu would FISH need to be ordered
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 2+ value OF Her2/neu on IHC is equivocal,hence, FISH is performed. If on FISH ,Amplification is present=then,patient is Her2/neu positive If on FISH ,Amplification is absent=then,patient is Her2/neu negative

questions.text: Inferior thyroid artery supplies which structures 1. Esophagus 2. Thymus 3. Thyroid 4. Parathyroid
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Inferior thyroid artery supplies:- 1. upper part of Esophagus 2. Thymus 3. Inferior part of Thyroid 4. All four Parathyroids

questions.text: A 30 years old female patient presented with complaints of palpitation and feeling febrile all the time with midline neck swelling. On examination, a diffusely enlarged thyroid is felt and lower border of swelling is seen moving with deglutition. Exophthalmos was also noted. What are the essential investigations to be done? 1. Thyroid scan 2. FNAC 3. Thyroid function test 4. USG neck 5. Anti-Thyroid antibody
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The given case scenario is s/o Thyrotoxicosis,secondary to Graves disease. 1. Thyroid scan is done to look for uptake. 2. FNAC is not needed in case of grave's disease as it is invasive and diagnosis can be done by clinical and radiological investigations. 3. Thyroid function test is done to look for increased T3 AND T4 and decreased TSH. 4. USG neck will reveal diffuse enlargement of thyroid. 5. Anti-Thyroid antibody is also sent to aid the diagnosis.

choices.text: May need amputataion in severe cases

questions.text: True regarding frost bite.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-May need amputataion in severe cases if the part undergoes gangrene. Option B-Antibiotics have a role as they will prevent infection in the affected part. Option C-REWARMING SHOULD BE DONE. Option D-Keep the area dry.

questions.text: X-ray is done in following cases of blunt trauma chest. In which of them, further investigations are required before inserting icd? 1. Flail chest 2. Pneumothorax 3. Diaphragmatic injury 4. Left sided pleural effusion/hemothorax.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 1 is Flail chest as ribs are fractured.Flail chest by itself is not an indication to put ICD. 2 is pneumothorax in which ICD should be put. 3 is diaphragmatic injury,in which ICD is contraindicated as it may cause injury to surrounding structures while inserting the tube. 4 is hemothorax in which ICD should be put.

questions.text: 37 Y female unmarried, nulliparous having regular intercourse, but not on OCPs. Mother had Carcinoma at 50 years of age. Sister had cancer at 40 years of age. What will you advise as next step?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-patient is already not taking OCPs. Option B-Mammography can be done in high risk patients after 30 years but 1st step will be BRCA testing. Option C-Since patient has family history of breast cancer,she is a High risk patient and must undergo Genetic counselling for BRCA. Option D-Immediate mastectomy is not done.

questions.text: Patient of RTA With grade-3 splenic trauma, on non-operative management in ward. What would be the reason for Laparotomy on second day of management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Fall in Hb more than 3gm would need laparotomy. Option B-Presence of Pneumoperitoneum would need laparotomy as there maybe perforation of hollow viscera. Option C-Extraperitoneum rupture of bladder is managed by putting Foley's catheter. Option D-Distended GB is not an indication for laparotomy.

choices.text: Pain on passive movements of the calf.

questions.text: Deep ulcer presented in the figure depicts?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The given image shows Trophic ulcer which occurs due to loss of sensation like as in diabetes.

questions.text: The correct statements is/are regarding the difference between SSG and Full thickness graft? 1. Primary contraction more with SSG 2. Secondary contraction more with SSG 3. Primary contraction more with full thickness grafts. 4. Secondary contraction more with full thickness grafts.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 1. Primary contraction is more with full thickness graft. 2. Secondary contraction is more with SSG.

questions.text: A 32 year female patient is on Tamoxifen after a breast cancer surgery. For around 5 years she was on Tamoxifen. When will she stop Tamoxifen if she wants to conceive?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) TAMOXIFEN IDEALLY SHOULD BE STOPPED MINIMUM 2 MONTHS BEFORE CONCEIVING.So,the best answer here out of the given options is 1 month before conceiving.

questions.text: Match the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The correct match is :- 1.polypropylene is used in hernia repair. 2.nylon is used for suturing of skin. 3.polygalactin/vicryl is used for bowel anastomosis. 4.polydioxanone is used for abdominal closure.

questions.text: Laparoscopy has all benefits except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Better cosmesis because of small incisions. Option B-Less pain also because of small incisions. Option C-Early ambulation can be done after laparoscopy. Option D-laparoscopy provides Early time for discharge,on same day discharge [concept of 23 hour admission].

questions.text: Which drug is used to reduce bleeding from thyroid?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Propranolol decreases T4 to T3 conversion but do not reduce bleeding. Option B-PTU inhibits thyroid peroxidase and decreases T4 to T3 conversion but do not reduce bleeding. Option C-Lugol’s iodine (KI) Makes thyroid gland less vascular due to vasoconstriction & less functional.It is given 10 to 14 days prior to surgery. Option D-Methimazole inhibits thyroid peroxidase but do not reduce bleeding.

questions.text: 19-year-old girl with a neck swelling which moves with deglutition and invading surrounding structures. Most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Thyroglossal cyst do not invade surrounding structures. Option B-The given image shows nuclear clearing known as Orphan annie eye nuclei,which is seen in PTC(papillary thyroid cancer).Also,it is invading surrounding structures which also favours diagnosis of malignancy. Option C-Medullary cancer thyroid will show amyloid stroma on HPE. Option D-Follicular adenoma will show multiple follicles with colloid in center of follicle.

questions.text: Match the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Thyroid is a superficial structure and can be biopsied by USG guided biopsy method. Breast biopsy is done by Tru cut biopsy. Lymph node usually can be excised as a whole,hence,Excisional biopsy will be done. Marjolin ulcer can be sampled by Incisional biopsy.

questions.text: SIRS does not include?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The criteria for SIRS include the following:- 1.Temp : <36 or>38 degree C 2.WBC : < 4000 or >12000/mm3 or more than 10% band forms in Peripheral smear. 3.RR : > 20/min or PaCO2 < 32mm Hg. 4.PR : >90/min Systolic blood pressure is not included in definition of SIRS.

questions.text: Not included in Damage control surgery is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Control contamination is done in phase 1 of DCS. Option B-Hemorrhage control is also done in in phase 1. Option C-Resuscitation is done in phase 2. Option D-Vascular anastomosis is Not included in Damage control surgery.

questions.text: An old lady fell down and presented after few days with headache and neurological symptoms. What is the source of bleeding?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Middle meningeal artery ruptures in EDH. Option B-Lenticular artery ruptures in intracerebral hemorrhage. Option C-Since lady presented after days of trauma,It is likely due to SDH(subdural hemorrhage),which occurs due to rupture of Bridging vessels. Option D-Anterior cerebral artery is less common site for rupture.

questions.text: Feature of neurogenic shock is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Neurogenic shock results in LOSS OF SYMPATHETIC TONE ->VASODILATATION IN PERIPHERY.THE NORMAL RESPONSE TO VASODILATION IS TACHYCARDIA but because of loss of sympathetic response In neurogenic shock, bradycardia is seen in patient.hence,patient will have Hypotension and bradycardia. Option B-Hypertension and bradycardia is seen in raised ICP. Option C-Hypotension and tachycardia is seen in hypovolemic shock. Option D-Hypertension and tachycardia can be seen in aortic dissection.

questions.text: Sequence of arrangement of following in RTA is? A. Cervical spine stabilization B. Intubation C. IV cannula D. Vital measurements
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) ABCDE of trauma care : - 1.Airway assessment and protection (maintain cervical spine stabilization when appropriate) 2.Breathing and ventilation assessment ( maintain adequate oxygenation,example by intubation) 3.Circulation assessment (check vitals and Control Hemorrhage):- Two wide bore (14 G to 16G) cannulae are inserted for iv fluid resuscitation 4.Disability assessment:-This is most commonly assessed by the Glasgow coma scale 5.Exposure ,with environmental control

questions.text: Not routinely used in the diagnosis of breast cancer?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The triple assessment method is used to evaluate a patient who presents with a breast lump or has any symptoms suspicious of CA breast. PET scan is not a part of the triple assessment method. Triple assessment of breast lump includes the following 3 parameters: - Clinical assessment: Clinical history and physical examination of the lump Radiological examination: USG or mammogram or both Cytological examination: FNAC or core biopsy of the lump . This is the most commonly used method as the PPV of this combination is 99.99%.

questions.text: All are contra-indications of breast conservation surgery except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Absolute contraindications of BCT : - 1.Pregnancy 2.Persistently positive margins 3.Multicentric lumps 4.Diffuse microcalcificatiom 5.Extensive DCIS 6.Inflammatory breast cancer Relative contraindications of BCT: - 1.Active SLE 2.Large lump to breast ratio ( > 5 cm size lump) 3.Known or suspected genetic predisposition to breast cancer (i.e, BRCA-1 , BRCA-2) , Li-fraumeni syndrome (P-53 mutation) 4.Multifocal disease 5.Prior Radiotherapy to chest wall or breast

questions.text: A 20-years-old male presents with hard painless testicular swelling. On investigation AFP is 308. No para aortic or iliac nodes as well as no mediastinal lymph nodes were found. USG shows uniform echotexture and small areas of necrosis. Surrounding structures are normal. What is the next best step:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A,B-FNAC and Trucut biopsy are contraindicated in testicular tumours as tumour may spread to scrotum. Option C-Since AFP values are high in this patient and USG is showing small areas of necrosis.It is Pointing towards diagnosis of non- seminomatous tumour→Do high inguinal orchidectomy. [In seminoma- AFP values are normal]. Option D-PET-CT is not routinely used for diagnosis of testicular tumour.

choices.text: Immediate scrotal exploration only on side of swelling
Immediate scrotal exploration on same side and delayed exploration on the other side
Immediate scrotal exploration on both sides

questions.text: If a child presents with acute scrotal pain and swelling where testicular torsion is highly suspected, how would you proceed:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Torsion testes:- Common in age of 10 to 20 years Commonest cause Clapper bell deformity Clinical test Prehn’s test to differentiate torsion from acute epididymo-orchitis. Scrotum is lifted up → pain → relieved→ acute epididymoorchitis. Pain → same or aggravated→ torsion IOC Doppler Treatment Bilateral scrotal exploration is done as in future torsion on other side can occur.

questions.text: Girl child with dribbling of urine but otherwise has normal voiding.what is the cause?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A,B,C-Grade 4 VUR,Ureterocele and Congenital Megaureter do not result in incontinence. Option D-TRUE INCONTINENCE + NORMAL VOIDING is Pointing towards ectopic ureter. This girl child will have 3 ureters → 2 are normal [Normal voiding], 1 is going to be ectopic In females, ectopic ureter opens below the external spnichter→ True incontinence. In males, ectopic ureter opens above the sphincter → Continence.

choices.text: Dribbling while asking the patient to lie in supine and asking to cough

questions.text: All of the following are lower urinary tract symptoms except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) LUTS refers to symptoms of bladder outlet Obstruction and is of 2 types- 1. Obstructive/ Voiding symptoms. 2. storage/irritative symptoms- because of detrusor hypertrophy. Option A-Incontinence during intercourse is a LUTS. Option B-Sudden urge to urinate is k/s urgency,which is a LUTS. Option C-Incontinence while asleep is k/s nocturia,which is a LUTS. Option D-Dribbling while asking the patient to lie in supine and asking to cough is k/s pseudo-incontinence and it is not a LUTS.

questions.text: Most common cause of bladder outlet obstruction in a male child?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Most common cause of bladder outlet obstruction in a male child is Posterior urethral valve- PUV. It shows Potters phenomenon/triad:- 1. Decreased fetal urine 2. Oligohydroamnios 3. Pulmonary hypoplasia

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient came to the outpatient department with complaints of hematuria. A 2x2 cm bladder mass was seen which is a high-grade transitional cell carcinoma. Which among the following is the ideal management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Urine for malignant cells → using NMP22 KIT [nuclear matrix protein] MRI > CECT for bladder cancer due to muscle invasion. Take home message Bladder Ca Most common malignancy of Bladder - transitional cell ca Smoking is most common cause [IMPORTANT] Superficial tumors as dangerous & problematic as invasive Non muscle invasive bladder carcinomas TURBT Intra-vesical BCG Muscle invasive bladder carcinoma Radical cystectomy is the treatment for External [ Preferred] / internal diversion Systemic MVAC [V : Vinblastine] Ca InSitu Intra-vesical chemotherapy In cases of too many recurrences → Radical cystectomy

questions.text: An elderly male, age 60 years patient presented with left testicular swelling and ataxia. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Germ cell tumour can also metastasize to Brain leading to neurological symptoms like ataxia. Option B-Glioblastoma multiform doesn’t occur in testes. Option C,D-NHL and hodgkin lymphoma :-CNS manifestations are not common.

questions.text: What is the correct volume of the prostate?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The correct volume of the prostate is 20cc.

questions.text: 30 year old male with blunt injury to the abdomen. There was no blood at tip of meatus. Nil urine output after Foley’s Catheterisation. The next best management for the patient is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The Diagnosis based on clinical picture is intraveBladder injury. Bladder injury is of Two types extra peritoneal:- Pelvic fracture associated Swelling in lower abdomen due to urine collection Tear drop sign seen on MCU Management may be prolonged catheterization. Intra-peritoneal seen in Trauma abdomen with full bladder Suspect when no urine output is seen after foley's. Management is laparotomy

questions.text: A Renal tumor with hematuria and a renal mass was seen on CT with hypodense shadow (negativeHU)?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-In RCC,the density of lesion on CT will be more i.e,hyperdense. Option B-Angiomyolipoma as the name suggests,contains fat.And fat has a negative HU value and is seen as a hypodense lesion.

questions.text: For a cancer of proximal transverse colon, which vessel should be ligated?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: Given Image is of Gas under diaphragm, best treatment is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Gas under diaphragm is seen in cases of perforation of hollow viscera. First is fluid resuscitation (Immediate treatment) but Best treatment is Laparotomy to repair the site of perforation. Plain X Ray signs of pneumoperitoneum:- Air under diaphragm (Best seen on erect Chest XR- IOC) [Gold standard for pneumoperitoneum: CT scan] Among all abdominal x ray best is: Left lateral decubitus view Doge’s Cap Sign (free Air in Morrison's Pouch) Rigler’s sign on supine AXR (also known as double-wall sign) Falciform Ligament Sign (Silver sign ) The ‘football’ sign Cupola sign. Air accumulation beneath the central tendon of the diaphragm The Inverted V sign

questions.text: A stomach tumour with spindle cell, C-kit positive (CD117) and S 100 positive and cytokeratin negative. Most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Adenocarcinoma is cytokeratin positive. Option B-GIST shows Spindle cell > epithelioid > Pleomorphic and CD 117>DOG1>BCL2 are markers of GIST. Stomach is most common site of GIST. Option C-Lymphoma do not show spindle cells. Option D-Sarcomatous tumour can show spindle cells but IHC markers favours diagnosis of GIST.

questions.text: Match the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Rat tail= Achalasia String sign = CHPS Football sign = Pneumoperitoneum Inverted umbrella sign = Ileo-caecal TB

questions.text: Most common site of TB?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Most common site of TB is Ileo-Caecal junction. Ulcerative type is more common than hyperplastic type.

questions.text: Identify the image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-The given image shows Coffee bean sign of sigmoid volvulus .It is Most commonly seen in old age. Option B-Pneumoperitoneum occurs due to perforation of hollow viscera. Option C-Caecal volvulus shows comma shaped sign. Option D-Midgut volvulus can show mesenteric whorl sign.

questions.text: Match the following in number of node removed with cancer surgery? A: Breast 1=10 B: Stomach 2= >15 C: Gall bladder 3=6 D: Colon 4=12
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The number of node removed with cancer surgery are as follows:- A: Breast =10 B: Stomach= >15 C: Gall bladder =6 D: Colon=12

choices.text: MRI to visualize pancreatic duct abnormality

questions.text: A patient was referred for acute necrotising pancreatitis with abdominal collection on CT scan. Patient is on vasopressors with BP 90/60 mmHg. What should be the initial therapy for this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) This is a case of acute necrotising pancreatitis with collection and it should be aspirated percutaneously.If there is no response on percutaneous aspiration,then open/lap methods can be tried.

questions.text: Patient had post appendectomy bleed. Which artery needs to be ligated?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A,B,C-SMA,Right colic artery and Middle colic supply small intestine and large intestine,hence,they should not be ligated at first. Option D-Appendix is supplied by appendicular artery which is a branch of Ileocolic artery,which itself is a terminal branch of SMA.Hence,Ileocolic artery should be ligated in cases of bleed.

questions.text: B12 deficiency is seen in resection of all except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Stomach produces intrinsic factor. Option B-Duodenum helps in breaking the protein bound B12 by release of enzymes. Option C-Jejunum has no role in B12 absorption. Option D-B12 is absorbed from Ileum.

questions.text: Which vaccine is not given after splenectomy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Typhoid vaccine is not given after splenectomy. Option B,C,D-Post splenectomy,there is increased risk of encapsulated bacterial infections,hence,patient should be given vaccine against encapsulated organisms such as Pneumococcal,Meningococcal and H influenzae vaccine.

questions.text: Which is done first in hypospadias surgery?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The operative steps of hypospadias surgery involve:- 1.penile degloving and correction of Ventral chordee (orthoplasty) 2.reconstruction of the urethra (urethroplasty) 3.reconstruction of the glans (glansplasty), and finally a cosmetic skin coverage.

questions.text: Not a Boundary of triangle of safety?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The triangle of safety is bordered by the pectoralis major anteriorly and latissimus dorsi posteriorly and the 5th intercostal space (roughly the level of the nipple in a thin male). The only muscles you need to go through to put ICD are the serratus anterior and intercostals. Posterior axillary line is not a boundary

choices.text: Pancreatitis without features of cholangitis or choledochal cysts

questions.text: ERCP is used for all of the following indications except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A,B,D-Recurrent pancreatitis,Unexplained jaundice and Periampullary carcinoma are the indications for ERCP. Option C-Pancreatitis without features of cholangitis or choledochal cysts is managed by conservative treatment.ERCP is not done in such cases.

questions.text: Patient with recurrent abdominal pain, USG was done and it comes out to be normal, on further evaluation by other investigation he was found to have biliary dyskinesia. which of the following is not done for diagnosis of biliary dyskinesia.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-HIDA scan will show a reduced gallbladder ejection fraction (EF) .A gallbladder EF<35% is considered diagnostic of Biliary dyskinesia Option B-The best investigation for the diagnosis of sphincter of oddi dysfunction is ERCP with manometry of the Biliary and pancreatic sphincters. Option C-MRCP can demonstrate dilatation of the Biliary and pancreatic ducts Option D-USG is the least useful investigation in the diagnosis of Biliary dyskinesia or Sphincter of oddi dysfunction since the findings can be normal or show non - specific changes such as dilatation of CBD.

choices.text: FNAC OR Biopsy required before surgery.
Leakage of the cyst can cause anaphylaxis

questions.text: State the wrong statement for the picture depicted
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The given CT image is s/o Hydatid cyst of liver. Option A-FNAC or Biopsy is not done as there is risk of anaphylaxis. Option B-Albendazole 400mg BD given 2 weeks before surgery & post op for 4 weeks. Option C-Caused by dog tapeworm(echinococcus granulosus). Option D-Leakage of the cyst can cause anaphylaxis is a true statement.

questions.text: Identify the specimen shown below.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Strawberry gallbladder refers to the surface appearance (not shape) of the mucosa of the gall bladder due to multiple small collections of triglycerides and cholesterol esters within the lamina propria of the gallbladder wall.Also known as cholesterolosis.Strawberry gallbladder represents diffuse cholesterolosis and is a common, idiopathic, non-neoplastic condition. Option B-Ca gall bladder may be seen as a focal lesion. Option C-Cholelithiasis can be easily identified by presence of stones. Option D-Multiple gall bladder polyps will be seen as multiple protrusions.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Bipolar cautery has 2 limbs and current passes between both the limbs Option B-monopolar cautery has 1 limb as shown in image. Option C-Harmonic scalpel uses ultrasonic energy with a range of 55,000Hz, seals [upto 5mm] [new upto 7mm] and divides the tissues. Option D-Ligasure is an advanced bipolar technique using body's own collagen to seal the blood vessel [upto 7mm].

questions.text: A patient of chronic liver failure presented with acute variceal bleeding. The BP was 80/60 mm Hg. Which of the following is not done?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Octreotide infusion is given in acute variceal bleeding to reduce blood loss. Option B-Endoscopic banding is treatment of choice. Option C-if Endoscopic banding fails,then,TIPSS is done. Option D-FFP is transfused not platelets in acute variceal bleeding.

questions.text: On 5th post operative day after cholecystectomy, there was some bile collection in Morrison pouch. What is the best investigation to diagnose and manage bile leak ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Initial investigation to diagnose bile leak is MRCP. Option B-ERCP is both diagnostic as well as therapeutic investigation Option C,D-HIDA and CECT are not routinely done to diagnose bile leak.

questions.text: In Strasberg classification of bile duct injury, transection of right sectoral duct is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Type A is cystic duct leak. Type B is occlusion of right aberrant right sectoral duct. Type C is transection of right aberrant right sectoral duct. Type D is lateral injury to major bile duct.

questions.text: Which instrument is not used in management of Upper GI bleed?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Image A is Modified Sengenstaken Blakemore tube Image B is Minnesota tube Image C is Upper GI endoscope Image D is simple bronchoscope,which obviously is not used in management of Upper GI bleed.

questions.text: Most common functional neuroendocrine tumor of pancreas:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Most common functional neuroendocrine tumor of pancreas in MEN-1 syndrome is gastrinoma. Option B,D-VIPoma and Somatostatinoma are also functional neuroendocrine tumor of pancreas but they're not the most common one. Option C-Most common functional neuroendocrine tumor of pancreas is Insulinoma.

questions.text: Smoking increases the risk of- 1. Duct ectasia 2. Fibroadenoma 3. Mondor’s disease 4. Breast carcinoma
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Duct ectasia (Zuska’s disease) is associated with smoking. Mondor’s disease is superficial thrombophlebitis of chest veins which appears like a cord-like swelling below the chest, is also associated with smoking. Breast carcinoma is also associated with smoking. Fibroadenoma is not associated with smoking.

questions.text: Which of the following steps are done in Breast Conservation Surgery? 1. Wide local excision 2. Axillary node dissection can be done 3. Frozen section (biopsy) can be done during surgery 4. Post-operative radiotherapy is optional
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Breast Conservation Surgery or lumpectomy is a surgical approach used to treat breast cancer while preserving the breast tissue. It typically involves 2 components:- 1. Lumpectomy- with 1 mm margin. 2. Radiation therapy is recommended after lumpectomy(it's not optional) to destroy any remaining cancer cells and reduce the risk of local recurrence. 3.Axillary node dissection can be done as well frozen section (biopsy) can be done during surgery.

choices.text: Usually symptomatic with dyspnoea, dysphagia and SVC syndrome
Chest xray is the investigation of choice.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true about thymoma?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Thymoma is the most common anterior (not posterior) mediastinal tumor. Option B-Most common neoplasm of thymus is thymoma. Option C-They are often related to myasthenia gravis, or may be asymptomatic as well. Option D-IOC is CECT thorax.

questions.text: In a patient with inguinal hernia, the surgeon reduces the entire hernial sac into the abdominal cavity without reducing the contents. What is this called?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) When a surgeon attempts to reduce an inguinal hernia, but instead of the contents sliding back into the abdominal cavity, the entire hernial sac (along with its contents) is pushed en masse through the defect and into the preperitoneal space, this is known as reduction en masse. This is a dangerous situation because the contents of the hernia, although apparently reduced from the external view, remain within the sac but are still outside the main peritoneal cavity. This means the contents are still susceptible to strangulation or obstruction, and the true nature of the reduction is missed, potentially leading to delayed diagnosis of complications. The other options are incorrect for the following reasons: B. Maydl's hernia: Maydl's hernia, also known as W-hernia, is a type of incarcerated or strangulated hernia where two loops of bowel are present in the hernial sac, and the connecting loop inside the abdominal cavity is strangulated. This is a specific type of complicated hernia, not a description of a reduction maneuver. C. Sliding hernia: A sliding hernia occurs when a retroperitoneal organ (like a part of the colon or bladder) forms part of the wall of the hernial sac, rather than just being contained within it. The organ "slides" into the hernia, and its reduction involves reducing the organ itself, not the entire sac as a separate entity. D. Incarcerated hernia: An incarcerated hernia refers to a hernia whose contents are trapped in the sac and cannot be manually reduced back into the abdominal cavity. While reduction en masse often occurs during an attempt to reduce an incarcerated hernia, "incarcerated hernia" describes the state of the hernia, not the specific complication of an incomplete reduction of the sac itself.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about claudication pain?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Pain on intermittent claudication does not come at the first step of walking, but after walking a certain distance called the maximum claudication distance. Pain on the first step of walking is seen in osteoarthritis. Option B-Rest pain is seen in the night due to ischemia to nerves. Option C-Most common cause of claudication pain is atheroma . Option D-The clinical stem does not reflect the site of peripheral arterial obstruction in intermittent claudication.

questions.text: A patient comes with dull aching pain in both legs. He gives a history of prolonged standing and tortuous veins in the legs. questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Brodie Trendelenburg Test is used for SFJ incompetence as well as perforators. Morrissey’s test is done for SFJ incompetence. Fegan’s test is done for only perforators. Modified Perthes test is a test for DVT.

questions.text: Post Orchidectomy, the specimen shows Reinke's Crystals.What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Seminoma shows nests of cells divided by septa with lymphocytic infiltrate. Option B-Reinke's Crystals are seen in Leydig Cell Tumor. Option C-teratoma cannot derivatives of all three germ layers. Option D-Yolk sac tumor shows schiller-duval bodies.

questions.text: Tumour Marker for choriocarcinoma is:-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) HCG (Human Chorionic Gonadotropin) Choriocarcinoma is a type of cancer that originates from trophoblastic tissue, and it produces elevated levels of HCG. This tumor marker is commonly used to diagnose and monitor treatment response in cases of choriocarcinoma. Here’s why the other options are not correct for choriocarcinoma: B. PLAP (Placental Alkaline Phosphatase): This marker is more commonly associated with germ cell tumors, such as seminomas, not choriocarcinoma. C. KIT: This is a marker for certain types of cancers like gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs), not choriocarcinoma. D. OCT 4: This is a stem cell marker associated with pluripotency and is seen in germ cell tumors, but not specifically in choriocarcinoma.

questions.text: An ulcerative lesion noted near the nose (medial canthus).What is the probable diagnosis?

questions.text: Diagnosis of given image is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Keratoacanthoma is a fast-growing, dome-shaped skin tumor that usually occurs on sun-exposed areas of the body, especially the head, neck, arms, legs, and back of the hands. Keratoacanthomas often begin in a hair follicle. Option B-Basal Cell Carcinoma/rodent ulcer is seen near medial canthus as ulcer with beaded margin. Option C-SCC can present as verrucous growth. Option D-Sebaceous horn appears elevated and pointed.

questions.text: In the anatomy of Inguinal canal, The fibres of internal Oblique and Transverse abdominis contribute to which components of inguinal Canal?

questions.text: Classification of bile duct injury taking location and thermal injury into duct and vessels into account ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Hannover classification takes into account: • Location of the bile duct injury • Presence of thermal injury • Injury to associated vascular structures (e.g., hepatic artery or portal vein) • It is a comprehensive system particularly used in cases of laparoscopic cholecystectomy-related injuries and provides valuable guidance for surgical management. Quick overview of the other options: A. Bismuth – Based on location of bile duct injury, especially strictures, mainly in post-cholecystectomy bile duct injuries. B. Strasberg – Expands on Bismuth, includes minor leaks and complete transections, mostly used for laparoscopic cholecystectomy injuries. C. Stewart-Way – Focuses on the mechanism of injury and surgeon's perception, not location or thermal damage.

questions.text: Which is not a risk factor for Ca Gall Bladder?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A,B,D-Porcelain Gall Bladder,Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis and Gallstone >3 cmare risk factors for gall bladder carcinoma. Option C-Polyp <10 mm is not a risk factor for cancer GB.

questions.text: On screening abdominal USG, a 12 mm sessile polyp was found incidentally in gall bladder, what should be the advise to the patient?

questions.text: Most important prognostic factor for CA Breast
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lymph Node (LN) Status Lymph node involvement is the strongest independent prognostic factor in breast cancer. The number of involved axillary lymph nodes directly correlates with the risk of recurrence and overall survival. While distant metastasis (option B) is crucial for staging and indicates a poorer overall prognosis, it is more reflective of current stage rather than a modifiable or early prognostic indicator. Tumor size (option C) and hormone receptor status (option D) also matter, but they are secondary to lymph node status in terms of prognosis.

questions.text: ER Open Cardiac massage is considered as what kind of wound

questions.text: A 35-year-old male sustained a head injury following a motorcycle accident. He experienced a brief loss of consciousness at the scene. questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with left lower lip weakness following a recent parotid gland surgery. Considering the surgical history and current symptoms, what is the most likely site of the lesion causing this patient's condition?

Option B-Temporal branch of facial nerve injury leads to paralysis of upper part of face. Option C-Cervical branch of facial nerve injury leads to paralysis of platysma. Option D-Parotid duct injury do not cause paralysis.

questions.text: POST LAPAROTOMY FOR PERFORATION PERITONITIS PATIENT ABDOMINAL WALL WAS CLOSED BUT SKIN WAS LEFT OPEN, WHICH WAS CLOSED ON 5th DAY. HOW THE HEALING OCCURS IN THIS CASE?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Primary intention healing, also known as first intention healing, involves the rapid closure of a clean wound with minimal tissue loss, typically achieved by bringing the wound edges together with sutures, staples, or adhesive strips, resulting in a faster healing process and less scarring. Option B-Healing by secondary intention involves an open wound closing naturally from the base upwards, without direct closure, often used for wounds with large tissue loss or those that cannot be safely closed with stitches. Option C-Tertiary intention, also known as delayed primary closure, involves initially leaving a wound open to allow for debridement and observation, then closing it later when conditions are appropriate.

questions.text: week old child, Non bilious vomiting, non projectile, abdominal examination normal DX?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) GERD (Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease). In a week-old child, the lower esophageal sphincter is often immature, leading to a common phenomenon where stomach contents easily flow back into the esophagus. This results in non-bilious (not green, as bile isn't involved at this level) and non-projectile (not forceful) vomiting, often appearing as "spitting up" or "wet burps." A normal abdominal examination is typical in these cases. While milk allergy can cause vomiting, it often presents with other symptoms like rash, diarrhea, or irritability, which are not mentioned here. Small bowel obstruction usually involves bilious vomiting and abdominal distension, making it unlikely. Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis (CHPS) characteristically presents with projectile non-bilious vomiting, usually later than one week of age (typically 3-6 weeks), which contradicts the "non-projectile" description.
